** translation of describtion **

Second World War, Airbattle. Building/ maintenance of a combatplane. Germany 1941

comment.author: 25404920@N08
comment._content:
Definitely no fighter. I agree with turkveil: Heinkel He.111 bomber because of its slightly asymmetrical nose (bending to the right a little).
Perhaps 'gevechtsvliegtuig' is better translated as 'combat plane', to avoid future miscommunication.

comment.author: 27223070@N04
comment._content:
I think we English readers get the 'jist'. She admits she is not a military translator. 
SYSTRAN  translates gevechtsvliegtuig to fighting plane. Golly gee pretty close gosh darn it 
I, for one doubt there is any miscommunication. ; p
Leenke  good job and thanks for your time & effort
Great set!

comment.author: 14673419@N00
comment._content: In Dutch bomber is  "bommenwerper". The Dutch caption of this undoubtably German picture  is probably made during  the war. Combat plane seems indeed to be a better translation

comment.author: 29802266@N07
comment._content:
val1009: Aside from the patently moronic interjection of 'olliebarwin' I don't see where anyone in this stream has offered a mean-spirited or hyper-critical remark.  People have merely spoken up when they have something constructive to add, such as the identity of the pictured aircraft.  Of course Leenke is doing a good job, that has not been disputed, but she has also graciously accepted input from those who have from time to time offered their esoteric knowledge, and she has frequently incorporated such information into her translation.  

Your chivalry is admirable, but you're tilting at windmills.

Anyway, the aircraft does appear to be a Heinkel 111 bomber.

comment.author: 12306929@N04
comment._content: I don't anything about airplanes so here goes............ isn't it more likely to be a building/rebuilding a bomber than maintaining one. ?
